S4.T1.caption: Table 1. Top-1 test accuracy (%) results on CIFAR10 under different device data heterogeneity and Edsubscript𝐸𝑑E_{d}. ”homo”/”hetero”: device model homogeneity/heterogeneity.
S4.T1.table:
Data heterogeneity IID NonIID
Feature Method/Edsubscript𝐸𝑑E_{d} 1 3 1 3
F FedAvg 57.36 59.75 52.36 56.96
FedGKT (homo) 66.78 67.90 38.88 44.59
FedGKT (hetero) 51.57 54.34 23.36 26.20
C2F FedAvg 61.81 66.32 57.09 62.69
FedGKT (homo) 78.44 79.05 30.91 57.70
FedGKT (hetero) 66.09 66.04 30.38 49.30
C&F FedDF 31.9 49.14 28.86 41.36
FedBE 38.28 51.55 31.73 43.09
ECCT (homo) 81.89 82.46 63.06 62.61
ECCT (hetero) 77.31 77.18 60.86 64.06
references:
In this section, experiments are conducted on CIFAR10 with synthetic feature split.
Table 1 shows the results under different device data heterogeneity and numbers of edge training epochs (Edsubscript𝐸𝑑E_{d}) using Dirichlet sampling (Lin et al., 2020) to assign devices with NonIID samples. Our method outperforms the baselines in both IID and NonIID settings. Moreover, our method shows a smaller decrease in performance compared with FedGKT when device model heterogeneity exists. Distillation (FedDF and FedBE) on the centralized features results in worse model performance, indicating that conventional FL methods cannot effectively utilize centralized features.

S4.T3.caption: Table 3. Top-1 test accuracy (%) results on CIFAR10 under different device numbers and device selection ratios.
S4.T3.table:
Device Num. 50 100
Select ratio 0.6 0.3 0.1 0.6 0.3 0.1
FedAvg 47.64 33.99 14.12 44.04 31.55 16.19
FedGKT 31.06 44.84 45.16 59.68 57.82 52.53
ECCT 68.43 68.68 45.33 78.36 75.91 67.01
references: Table 3 showcases the performance of different methods with various device numbers and selection ratios. Our ECCT outperforms FedAvg and FedGKT under all settings and is more tolerant with different participation of edge devices.

S4.T4.caption: Table 4. CTR prediction for Avazu.
S4.T4.table:
Feature F C2F C&F
Method FedAvg FedGKT FedAvg FedGKT ECCT
AUC 0.5783 0.5293 0.6595 0.5246 0.6694
MSE 0.1370 0.1488 0.1320 0.1559 0.1373
references: Firstly, we conduct experiments on Avazu for CTR prediction tasks and demonstrate the results in Table 4. Our method is superior to FedAvg and FedGKT in terms of AUC, even moving all the centralized features to the edge (”C2F”). Secondly, we test the methods on IndustryData for CTR and CVR prediction tasks. The results in Table 5 illustrate that our edge-cloud collaborative framework performs better than the FL methods, especially in the CVR task. It shows that the framework has large potential in the industry, especially for online recommendations.

S4.T5.caption: Table 5. CTR and CVR predictions for IndustryData.
S4.T5.table:
Task CTR CVR
Method/Metric AUC MSE AUC MSE
FedAvg 0.6829 0.0879 0.8145 0.0199
FedGKT 0.5409 0.1023 0.6068 0.0262
ECCT 0.6885 0.0875 0.8754 0.0184
references: Firstly, we conduct experiments on Avazu for CTR prediction tasks and demonstrate the results in Table 4. Our method is superior to FedAvg and FedGKT in terms of AUC, even moving all the centralized features to the edge (”C2F”). Secondly, we test the methods on IndustryData for CTR and CVR prediction tasks. The results in Table 5 illustrate that our edge-cloud collaborative framework performs better than the FL methods, especially in the CVR task. It shows that the framework has large potential in the industry, especially for online recommendations.
